fields_of_interest: Agriculture, Trade, Consumers, Culture, Education and training, Employment and Social Affairs, Environment, Regional Policy, Research and innovation, Public Health, Food Safety
eu_initiatives: Pollinators; Apis mellifera; Honey bees; EU Pollinators Initative; Habitats Directive; Natura 2000
subsection: Non-governmental organisations, platforms and networks and similar
goals__remit:
For the sake of longevity of the European honey bee species (Apis mellifera), some colonies of honeybees need to be given the opportunity to evolve on their own, ideally without human intervention, to adapt to their environment as they have done so for the last 1.6 million years. These colonies can then find their own solutions to climate change, diseases, and pests. These colonies are "unmanaged honey bees". 
At the same time, some colonies will continue to be kept by humans in beehives of all shapes and sizes with human management and human selective breeding. These colonies are "managed honey bees". 
Honey Bee Wild, a group of volunteers, organises events and activities that will contribute to changes to allow honey bees to live with as little human intervention as possible.
